awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Organic Cation Interactions with Soil Aluminosilicates:  Structure-Sorption Relationships
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation, addresses the need for more robust predictors of organic cation interactions with aluminosilicate minerals.  Professors Allison MacKay and José Gascon (University of Connecticut) and Dharni Vasudevan (Bowdoin College) in their collaboration will work closely with high school students and teachers to introduce cutting-edge chemistry concepts into public education. Their research activities provide two exciting and coupled avenues to facilitate increased K-12 chemistry literacy: Environmental issues, which are hot topics, and computer-based tools, which permeate our daily lives. The PIs will mentor post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate researchers through the processes of experimental design, manuscript preparation, and presentations at national professional societies. The PIs will continue their committed record of engaging student researchers from groups underrepresented in the sciences and engineering. The integrated team expertise in engineering (MacKay), chemistry (Vasudevan), molecular modeling (Gascon) and geochemistry (Collaborator Bourg) will enable research team members to develop broader perspectives of their individual research projects.

The collaborators will adapt computational biochemistry tools to the prediction of charged organic compound sorption, an important determinant of mobility, reactivity, and bioavailability of pesticides and pharmaceuticals following environmental release to soils.  The application of computational tools to environmental chemistry will advance our understanding of structure-sorption effects that are difficult to extract solely from experimental observations. This project examines application of the Linear Interaction Energy (LIE) approximation, a molecular dynamics approach with significant computational cost reductions, to identify contributions of van der Waals and electrostatic energies to overall sorption free energies for test sorbates on the representative soil aluminosilicate, montmorillonite. Results from this research will include mechanistic insights into sorption of environmental contaminants categorized as cationic amines to aluminosilicate minerals. This will advance the development of sorption models, allow the evaluation of LIE approximation methods for environmental chemistry applications, and provide integrated training for a research team of students from Primarily Undergraduate and Research 1 institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project to study "Organic Cation Interactions with Soil Aluminosilicates" addresses the absence of structure-sorption relationships to predict the fate and mobility of organic cations in soil systems.  Many organic contaminants of environmental concern are positively charged organic cations, such as human and verternary antibiotics, surfactants, and pharmaceutical compounds.  Methods to predict the sorption, or binding, of these compounds to environmental solids are not available presently, in part because the influence of organic cation structure is not well-known.  We focused on a model aluminosilicate system, montmorillonite and related clay minerals, and used a test set of organic cations with systematic variations in sorbate structure.  We obtained sorption coefficients as equilibrium measures of teh extent to which organic cations distribute between solid and aqueous phases.  We applied quantum mechanics calculations to understand electron distributions around organic cations and close to the aluminosilicate clay surfaces, both through the calculation of electrostatic potentials.  The results from this study have allowed deeper insights into the molecular driving forces that govern cation exchange interactions at charge surfaces.

Role of inorganic cation: Environmental surfaces with negative charge sites show charge neutrality through the close association of inorganic cations.  It was already well-known that the non-charged portio of an organic cation provides a great enough driving force to displace inorganic cations from environmental surfaces, even at orders of magnitude lower concentrations.  We were interested to know whether inorganic cations exert a regular influence on the exchange process with an organic cation.  We found that this is the case because we observed organic cation sorption coefficients were attenuated to the same extent when single-ion montmorillonite clays were prepared and compared to sodium-saturated montmorillonite.  A regular sequence of increasing competition to organic cation sorption was demonstrated with an ordering of sodium, ammonium and potassium, calcium and magnesium, and aluminum.  The thermodynamic contribution of these competing inorganic cation exchange reactions were quantified for any homoionic clays.

Role of aluminosilicate clay mineralogy:  Smectite clays, including montmorillonite, all share a similar crystal mineralogy with some important distinctions - negative charge site distributions between the surface tetrahedral layer and the einternal octahedral layer change across clay types and interlayer cations may cause the clay layers to be expandable or to collapse permanently.  We were interested to understand how these aluminosilicate clay features may contribute to sorption interactions of organic cations.  We dound that orgnaic catiosn with defocussed charge, that is, compounds with the positive amine charge spread across multiple atoms showed the greatest difference in cation exchange-normalized sorption coefficients across the test clays.  We used quantum mechanics calculations to quantify the electrostatic potential in the volume space between two layers of expandable smectite clays by constructing models for hectorite, montmorillonite, vermiculite and nontronite.  These calculations showed there to be an increasingly higher barrier to sorption (positive electrostatic potential) close to the surface of aluminosilicates as the fraction of clay total permanent charge wsa located in the tetrahedral layer.  Hectorite with almost no tetrahedral charge sites showed the greatest sorption of organic cations with defocused charge, while nontronite with almost all tetrahedral charge sites showed the lowed sorption of organic cations with defocused charge.  Similar trends were observed for organic cations with polar functional groups, indicating that the overall importance of aluminosilicate charge-site distributions occurs as an interplay of clay mineral features with organic cation structure.

Broader Impacts:  The understanding of a regular influence of inorganic cations on the sorption of organic cations suggests that organic cation exchange compounds can be used to probe systematically the available cation exchange capacity for a given environmental solid to take up other organic cations.  Indeed some preliminary efforts to extent our mechanistic finds from the model montmorillonite system to realistic environmental soils showed stronger correlations between sorption coefficients of organic cations with those for phenyltrimethylammonium than with direct measures of soil cation exchange capacity.  Coupling of phenyltrimethylammonium sorption coefficients for a given soil with some literature reported multi-linear regressions did yield estimates of compound sorption that were within a factor of two of measured values.

The technique of quantifying near surface electrostatic potential for large materials through the construction of point-maps to demonstrate the volume distribution of electrostatic potential has applications to understanding near-surface charge effects for other materials.
